typedef INT AudioReference::SoundDataSource
 

Specifies where and how sound data is obtained. See PredefinedSoundDataSource. Extension (non-predefined) values must avoid overlap (with predefined values and among each other).

enum AudioReference::PredefinedSoundDataSource
 

Predefined values for SoundDataSource.

Enumerator:
InvalidSoundDataSource  Should not be used by the application.
FileSoundDataSource  File based playback.
RamSoundDataSource  RAM based playback.
StreamSoundDataSource  Streaming based playback.
PresetSoundDataSource  Audio driver built-in sounds.
BinDataSoundDataSource  BinData based playback.
UnknownSoundDataSource  Unknown sound data source.
FmRadioSoundDataSource  FM Radio playback.
PredefinedSoundDataSourceEnd  Any user defined data sources should use this as baseline.

AudioReference::BalanceLevel AudioReference::GetBalance (   )  const [virtual]
 

Not supported, this is for future use. Gets the current balance setting. The returned value is in the range -100 to +100. -100 means the sound is output only on the left speaker. Per default the sound is centered.

Returns:
balance setting

AudioReference::ChannelNumber AudioReference::GetNumberOfChannels (   )  const [virtual]
 

Gets the number of channels. The base class returns 1 because only SMAF/PhraseL1 have channels. See SetChannel().

Reimplemented in CustomSmafPhraseAudioReference.

void AudioReference::SetBalance (  BalanceLevel  value  )  [virtual]
 

Not supported, this is for future use. see GetBalance for range of value. If a value out of range is supplied it is corrected to be in-range.

void AudioReference::SetChannel (  ChannelNumber  val  ) 
 

If this type of sound can be played simultaneously with another sound, then the various sounds play on channels. The channel index starts at 1. See GetNumberOfChannels().

void AudioReference::SetChannelVolume (  VolumeLevel  val  )  [virtual]
 

If the sound to be played has only one channel then this is the same as calling SetVolume().

void AudioReference::SetContinue (  BOOLEAN  val = TRUE  )  [inline]
 

Set the continue flag of a audio reference (used internally by the priority manager).

Parameters:
val Please consult the priority policy documentation

void AudioReference::SetPriority (  PriorityType  val  ) 
 

Use a higher priority to allow your sound to interrupt another lower-priority sound that is currently playing.

void AudioReference::SetPriorityGroup (  PriorityGroupType  group  ) 
 

Sets the priority group. The default value is always 1.

Note:
Definition of the priority group: A gruop is a family of sounds defined by application layer that are supposed to be prioritized using SetPriority(). The sounds being part of the same group will not be allowed to play in parallel. If a use case requires a parallel playback and the actual hardware supports it, a second priority group can be defined. The priority manager will allow the playback of two sounds from two different priority groups at the same time. The maximum number of parallel groups is determined depending on hardware capabilities. Example: Hardware supports two midi sounds played in parallel Sound A (midi type) played from SoundBrowser Sound B (midi type) played as a key tone
Use case requires that Sound A and B played simultaneously

Resolution: SoundA::SetPriorityGroup(1); SoundB::SetPriorityGroup(2);

void AudioReference::SetRate (  const INT32  rate  ) 
 

MIDP2.0, sets rate.

MIDP2.0 support. SetRate, it sets rate.

Parameters:
rate. Audio reference rate.
Returns:

void AudioReference::SetRepeatCount (  UINT16  repeat_count = 0  )  [inline]
 

Sets the repeat count. Note: It is the responsibility of the AudioPlayer to play the sound as many times as the repeat count specifies.

Parameters:
repeat_count The sound will be repeated repeat_count times. If 0 then repeat indefinitely (until stopped).

MIDP2.0.

void AudioReference::SetTimeout (  UINT32  timeout  ) 
 

Set the time-out in milliseconds. When the time-out occur the playing instance will be stopped. By default there is no time-out. Due to resource consumption the time-out option should be used only if really needed

void AudioReference::SetTone (  ToneLevel  value  )  [virtual]
 

Not supported, this is for future use.

void AudioReference::SetVolume (  VolumeLevel  val  ) 
 

If this method is not used, the AudioPlayer's volume will be used.

Parameters:
val The desired volume - the valid range is between 0 and 100. Setting the value 0 means silent.
